description: How is architecture fundamentally linked to acts of extraction? This walk visits everyday spaces and objects in King's Cross to explore extractive capitalism and its consequences: climate and ecological breakdown.

factsheet.heading: Acts of Extraction
paragraphs:
How is architecture fundamentally linked to acts of extraction? What forms of extraction can we observe in the built environment today? In this event, we will take you on a walk around Kings Cross starting at Granary Square, using everyday objects and spaces to elaborate on a set of ideas about extractive capitalism and its consequences: climate and ecological breakdown. 
Extraction is both material and immaterial: knowledge, labour, and capital are extracted as much as materials and energy. Spinning out stories that touch on all these aspects of extraction, we will not only be critical about the ways in which the built environment reflects extractivist processes, but also consider possibilities for other ways to act as we face the climate emergency.

factsheet.heading: About Us
paragraphs: Your guides on this walk are members of Mould, a team of architects and academics working at the intersection between spatial practice and the climate emergency.
We are based at Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London, and Technische Universität Braunschweig.

Our current project is Architecture after Architecture: Spatial Practice in the Face of the Climate Emergency, funded by the UK Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) and the German Research Foundation (DFG).
Our team: Tatjana Schneider, Christina Serifi, Anthony Powis, Jeremy Till, Becca Voelcker, Sarah Bovelett, Julius Grambow.
Please get in touch with us at mail@MOULD.earth if you would like to collaborate.
To learn more about Mould and Architecture after Architecture, please visit http://mould.earth/

name: Acts of Extraction - A Walking Tour in Ten Acts
